data.text: A stone coffin, often inscribed or decorated with sculpture.
data.attributionText: from The American HeritageÂ® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A species of stone used among the Greeks for making coffins. It was called by the Romans lapis Assius, from being found at Assos, a city of the Troad.
A stone coffin, especially one ornamented with sculptures or bearing inscriptions, etc.
A peculiar wine-cooler forming part of a dining-room sideboard about the end of the eighteenth century: it was a dark mahogany box, lined with lead.

A species of limestone used among the Greeks for making coffins, which was so called because it consumed within a few weeks the flesh of bodies deposited in it. It is otherwise called <altname>lapis Assius</altname>, or <altname>Assian stone</altname>, and is said to have been found at Assos, a city of Lycia.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: A coffin or chest-shaped tomb of the kind of stone described above; hence, any stone coffin.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: A stone shaped like a sarcophagus and placed by a grave as a memorial.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: The cement and steel <xref>structure</xref> that <xref>encases</xref> the destroyed <xref>reactor</xref> at the <xref>power station</xref> in Chernobyl, Ukraine.

data.text: a stone coffin (usually bearing sculpture or inscriptions)
